newsitem.title: OMAN: Oman's sultan endorses changes to company tax law.
newsitem.headline: Oman's sultan endorses changes to company tax law.

text.p: Oman's Sultan Qaboos bin Said has endorsed amendments to the company taxes law to lure foreign capital needed to diversify its oil-based economy, officials said on Monday.
They gave no details of the changes, endorsed by a royal decree issued late on Sunday.

The new law, expected to be published in the official gazette by the end of October, could encourage local firms to attract foreign investors, who have so far been few because of discriminatory tax laws.
Tax rates on local firms range from 3.0-7.5 percent while those companies with foreign participation pay 15-25 percent.
Unlike many big oil producers in the region, Oman allows foreign stakes in its oilfields, which produce 850,000 barrels per day. But foreign capital is scarce outside the oil sector .
Foreigners, apart from nationals of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, invest in only 12 of 74 companies listed on its stock market.
